Hi There!

This site is dedicated to an application assigment for the position of
Customer Success Specialist with ShopStorm

About Me

Who are you? Why are you a good fit for this role?

I'm Michael. I am a husband, father, and Audible addict, living in Southern California. I dearly love my family, love to learn, love to work, and love Lord of the Rings. I currently work full time for Formation Technologies as a support agent and graphic designer. I also work as an independent contractor for Rev'd Media, helping to lead their publication Slam'd Magazine. In addition to these efforts in my career path, I am a full-time Graphic Design student and maintain a small, but steady number of freelance design projects. Hy hobbies coincide pretty closely with my work. I thoroughly enjoy drawing, writing, and exploring new art projects. To be honest, I’m not sure how to go about continuing to describing myself. I could list favorite artists or movies (Kendrick Lamar and Jaws), talk about my dog (Strider is the most amazing husky in the universe), or recount pivotal life moments that may have shaped me as a person (not really that exciting), but none of that feels particularly natural. Instead I think its helpful to just state what my passion boils down to as plainly as possible.

I feel inescapably tied to the human need for creative expression. Each and every soul is uniquely capable of expressing itself. For me its takes on a variety of outlets revolving around design and arts. Nevertheless, the confidence I have in this framework of how to view life, has led me to work in a tech support role. I like technology a lot and I love design, but more importantly, feeling as though I know how I ought to express myself as a human, I operate in a vocation which allows me to help others do the same. Currently managing a Helpdesk for educational clients means that day in and out, I am aiding teachers and other school faculty to use their tech tools to the best of their abilities, in order to carry out their passion for education. Helping people do what they love, in efficient and fluid ways, is what makes me love my job. Its also why I think I would be an excellent fit for the position of Customer Success Specialist.

Explain a scenario where you had to tell a customer “no” or had to correct their mistake

Working in Tech Support, the situation in which the best answer to a user’s questions is “no” does indeed arise. Coinciding is the fairly regular need to a correct a mistake. As an example of this, just this past week I received a somewhat frantic support request ticket from a user, describing a problem with the trackpad of their laptop. This user typically uses a USB mouse with their device, however while prepping for a meeting outside their office, they noticed that the trackpad was not working. I received the Zendesk notification for the request on my phone, while working with a different user at their desk. Just as I finished reading the notification, the user’s who’s desk I was sitting at, asked me to diagnose an issue they were having with streaming music from their device. Knowing that the the ticket notification I had just recieved required quick attention for the sake of the requestor’s meeting, I told the second requestor that I had to first help the other with their track pad issue (essentially telling them “no, I can't help with your request regarding streaming at this time”). Luckily, the second requestor was understanding and saw the reason for me delaying support.

In regards to the first request, I had a diagnosis for the trackpad issue in mind, knowing there is a common mistake made by users with that laptop model. As I suspected, the trackpad was showing an amber LED indicator in the corner, meaning the user had inadvertently locked the trackpad by double-tapping the upper right corner. I showed the user it was a very easy thing to do unknowingly and how it could be helpful in the right context. The user was relived to know it was a very quick solution and would not hinder their quickly appraoching meeting. After helping solve the support request for the track pad issue, I was then able to help the second requester with their music streaming issue, in a timely manner.

Do you believe the customer is always right?

Whether or not a customer is always right, is a fairly commonplace question in the Tech Support industry. With my particular experience, mostly working with educational and small business clients, equally common place seems to be the notion that “tech guys” are the first to point out when a customer or user is not right. In an effort to combat negative stereotype of the mutant nerd sitting across the Helpdesk, I pursue balancing a “customer is always attitude” with some technological realism, to build trust and light-heartedness as it relates to tech support.

Just yesterday in fact, a user was having trouble locating the contents of a google doc they had been trying to copy and paste. According to the user they highlighted the text and then, “it all deleted itself”. Knowing that computers don’t do such things of their own accord, I figured a simple missed keystroke was to blame and this was just basic user error. In this case, the customer was not right. That didn’t really matter though. The point of my role in the scenario was not to press the user until they admited fault for a miniscule error that anyone is capable of making, but to show them a simple and helpful solution. I showed the user the Google Doc Edit History feature and we were able to restore to a previous version containing the full contents of their document. I then helped the user copy and paste the contents they way they had originally intended.

There are certainly cases where a customer may be in the wrong, but very rarely in the context of tech support does the case call for me to point it out. As the question pertains to customer service in areas of sales, retail, and purchases, the answer is similar however varies slightly. In my opinion it is better for a service/goods provider to assume fault in regards to customer service issues and go above in beyond in order to make amends for the problem and/or inconvenience. A genuine apology and effort to rectify a problem are invaluable means of customer satisfaction and retention. A company who invests in people invests in its own success.

What is your favorite GIF or emoji?

A Day in the Life

PRE-SALES: Imagine a potential customer emails you with the following question. We don’t yet offer this feature, but their current solution does. How would you respond?

“I’m considering switching to Product Customizer. Does your app allow live image previews?”

Hi there,

We are excited that you are taking a look at out Product Customizer App. In an effort to truly allow freedom for you as a Shopify merchant, the Product Customizer App allows you to add any number of customization options for a given product. Unfortunately it does not currently allow for live image previews.

We are continuing to develop our apps and support them in the best ways that we can. We hope to be offering a feature for live image previews of customizable products in the near future.

In the meantime, we hope that some of the other key features of the Product Customizer will still make your life as a merchant easier and more successful. Please don’t hesitate to reach out to our team with any more questions you may have.

Thanks so much!

- Michael

FIRE ALARM: Imagine you’ve just started your workday. You login and see a large number of emails from distraught customers. Clearly, something is happening. What steps do you take?

Upon logging in to start my workday and seeing a large number of emails from distraught customers, my first order of business would be to throw on a comically large head-set, take a drawn-out sip of coffee while maintaining eye contact with my monitor , quietly and raspily say, “buckle-up” to no one in particular, and then smash the big button on my desk that triggers sirens, strobe lights, and signifies the situation being elevated to DEFCON 5. Just kidding.

In reality, I would skim the emails in my inbox and try and access whether or not there is a common thread amongst the many problems. If all the request seem to be stemming from the same root issue, I would then as quickly as possible work in concentric support steps to diagnose the problem. If multiple users are having the same issue, its fair to assume it is not a user-end problem. From there, determine where the problem is most likely originating from. At this point I would reach out to other support team members to either see if they are receiving similar emails and if not to give them a potential warning. I would then reach out to the development team to see if they are aware that users are experiencing a problem and if so, what may be causing it. Once I have some hard facts to report, I would begin replying to all of the distraught customers in the order in which they were received. With calm and concise replies, I would state that we are aware of the problem, actively seeking to resolve and prevent it, and most importantly deeply apologetic for any inconveniences and interruptions. I would then balance my efforts between offering follow up support to customers as their replies came in, preemptive support where applicable, and aiding other teams in anyway I can to help resolve the issues.

If it happened that the many emails were actually unrelated and there were several coincidental cases of customers needing serious support, I would asses which customers problems and circumstances demanded the highest priorities. I would then respond to each email in turn, letting them know we would be offering our help as quickly as possible. Then, for the highest priority issue I would begin support. If appropriate I would reach out to other members of the support team and let them know that there was a high volume of emails I had received and ask if thy would be able to help resolve some of the issues in an effort to most quickly and efficiently achieve customer success.

STEP-BY-STEP: We’d like to get an idea of how you explain concepts and processes. What was the last thing your purchased online? Tell us, step-by-step, how you went about searching, choosing, and completing your purchase.

Recently I purchased a new outdoor Dog Run for my husky, Strider. I began the process by determining what I was looking for specifically and searching on google an item that included the most important features. After searching “dog kennel 6ft” I used the google shopping tab to order the search results with accompanying images. I then looked for a dog run that was 6ft high and combined the best price, customer rating, and overall size for our needs. After finding the specific product I wanted, I then did a second google search of the specific item to find a possibly cheaper price for it. Determining that Walmart had the best overall price, including taxes and shipping, I placed it in my online cart. In the checkout section, the Google Chrome App, Honey then automatically searched for and applied any available coupon codes to further reduce the price. I then placed the order knowing I got the best possible online price for the item that combined all of the necessary features in an outdoor dog run for our pup.
